From what I read in a 2019 article, Contractors doing work for the US Navy, are installing special filters to where shower water goes to be filtered for reuse on all US Submarines.... What the basic problem has been since 1998 is, sperm can cause an issue with the filters clogging up.


So the answer to the problem was all sailors onboard have a DNA card, which can be matched to what the sample's DNA is. Next the crew member would receive 1 (one) Demerit. Then, while on tour, if any one person receives over a certain amount of demerits, they will be pulled from their sub & transferred to an older sub that is in ''Dry-Dock'' for Upgrades. Your ID Badge is printed on different colored paper, so even the ''New-Bees'' know why the person is there. (The Code Name is called, ''Peeing-In-The-Pool'')....

Today it's in the Supreme Court being challenged. Attorney's hired to represent defendants are claiming that it's within the civil rights of any American Serving in the US Military to be able to ''Spank the Monkey'' as many times as they want. Why this issue wasn't mentioned in the video is because it's still being considered a Classified Matter, under Article 21, Subsection 5e, Paragraph C, which states that all persons currently serving that, ''STM'' is still considered to be within their Civil Rights......

It will be interesting to see how this pans out.... Perhaps he'll edit the ''Shower'' part of this video & add it, or just do a companion video in Dumber-Every-Day, Spanking-The-Monkey.

Those bunks are very similar to life on a concert tour which I've done off and on for thirty years.  The standard bunks are probably a little tighter than the standard three high on a tour bus, but the officers bunks are very similar to what we call a condo bunk which are two high.  Unlike the Navy, we in touring life get off the bus every day and get hotel rooms several days a week to spread out and organize ourselves.  What I want to know is how and who does the laundry.  We just send a dirty duffle out in the morning with a list of quantities and payment and the clean laundry is delivered back later in the afternoon.

As a recreational diver, I would say a very challenging thing on a sub may medical emergencies and atmospheric pressure. Air volume, blood clotting, and the effect of medication are all affected by atmospheric pressure.  Even cooking for the crew is an issue because the pressure does affect the taste buds! Maybe better stated as it changes the brain's sensation to taste. Great video!!

I had the rover watch on board the James Madison way back when.  The COW called down to lineup the #4 sanitary tank to blow.  This is what I did, or so I thought.  Word came down to commence blowing.  The very instant that I hit the pressurization valve vivid pictures in my feeble brain showed the toilet flapper valve open!  Too late,  I instantly closed the valve but the "dirty" deed had already happened.  Of course word quickly got around the boat so I had a few interested visitors.  They all volunteered to help but I told them that it was my mistake and I would clean it up.  It took a few days of ribbing before things got back to a normal routine.  I did 8 patrols out of the Loch and never forgot that snafu!  Cheers mates!

That's why they kept censoring those messages.

20yrs on submarines to include 637 class fast attacks and an SSBN. 637 had ball valve toilets and SSBN's have a real porcelain toilet like your home and flushes the same. I have been playing cribbage since a little boy. My dad took the game very seriously.  Once you played for a couple of games he would induce the “mugging” rule. Id also like to point out that officers on a sub are the smartest in the entire Navy. On a carrier I was enlisted and I met some of the dumbest officers in the whole GD WORLD who flew jets but had degrees in MFin BASKET WEAVING. Not really but seriously some of these dudes had some of the most BS degrees ever.. In physical education or in some off the wall “never need to show up” class. Passed college with barely a C average while they get treated like a king and enlisted members who have more experience in the Navy, more intelligence and more common sense get treated like GD children. “Be back to the ship you 38 year old enlisted first class. Only chiefs and goofy green horn officers with the intelligence of a ice cube get treated like actual adults and can come back whenever the heck they want.. Its BS.. Now i have both a masters and a bachelors degree thanks to the navy but was too old to join back up. Their should be an entry test for officers plain and simple. Heck when I was in the Navy you could become a warrant officer with just an associates. But they are still basically treated like enlisted officers even though you still call them sir and ma’am. I could sit here and write an epic length novel on all the dumb BS officers have done while their troubles get swept under the rug just for an enlisted member to get a captains masts for racing the XO of the attached helicopter squadron on foot (not knowing the enlisted person he was challenging was an ex rugby player with insane speed and beat him like he was only working with one leg.) The XO got mad that he lost and then in front of like 20 witnesses tried making up a story about my buddy running from him when there were both witnesses that the XO challenged him to a race back to the ship (because my buddy lost his liberty buddy, which if that ever happens you must find a shore patrolman, who was the XO at the time, and you must tell the where you lost them and go back to the ship.) AND there were races that once my buddy passed the agreed upon finish line he stopped and waited for the XO to catch up.. Drunk and laughing of course because he was on liberty.. Well the XO got mad and made up and entire story and even though they brought in multiple witnesses into the captains masts contradicting the XOs story and NOT ONE witness for the XO, my buddy STILL got in trouble and it was a strike against his three strike ARL (alcohol related incident) rule the Navy adopted while on cruise. Ive seen this many times where officers words were taken over multiple witnesses.

Like when I was thrown into a captains mast for taking my guns out fo the armory and storing them in my barracks closet because when I was at a base party thrown by a bunch of the base Master At Arms command I met one of the chiefs from the armory who was hanging out with all the enlisted and we got to talking about how many awesome guns were in the armory and then the chief proceeded to laugh and tell me how the officers pick trigger locks and take any gun they want out shooting. Then he laughed even more when he said sometimes they will even break weapons and put they back and act like they were broken the entire time. I thought they were joking because I told them I had my guns in the base armory and he then got all serious and was like “No son, I ain’t joking. I just think its funny that these officers act like children when some of my airman act more mature than they do”. So I took my guns out of the armory, stored them in my barracks and was caught with them during a bi yearly health and wellness check they do on our closets. I guess cause some dude had an animal that died in his closet one time or something.. Anyways I got caught with my guns and when I went to captains mast and told my CO why i did that he got all pissed off and was all like “You expect me to believe the commanding officer will let his officers and MAs break the rules and commit crimes against the UCMJ? Are you saying our officers are criminals, are you saying they are dumb? Putting MFing worlds in my mouth when all I was doing was giving them the exact reason why I did what I did. He called me a liar and threatened to have a joint Captains Mast with the MA command of our base NAS Lemoore and bring every single MA in to interrogate them to see if this really happens. Like any one of them would admit to picking trigger locks, taking someone else’s weapon and then accidentally breaking it and putting it back like it was always like that.. YEAH… Like that would happen.. It took all my strength not to laugh in his face with all my chiefs and officers sitting there watching. That was partly why me and many others I knew got out of the Navy.. All this BS where ignorance and blind support of your officers no matter how heinous is the rule of the day. But at least I got two degrees out of it all.

If he wants to truly experience how the “working half” lives, then he needs to find someone on an aircraft carrier and do what is called a “tiger cruise”. Carriers are the best I think.  They aren’t common and ships do them very sporadically. My chief was in the Navy for 15 years and he only experienced 2 or 3 Tiger Cruises.  Anyway, what happens is half the ship leaves once you get to a certain “safe port”.  Ours was Hawaii and our destination was San Diego.  Well then family members and friends can then get on the ship and do a week or so cruise back to their home port.  My dad and brother got to sleep in my very own birthing cube.  It was so funny listening to them wack their heads on the rack above them lol.. I tried telling them the best bunks were the top bunks but they didn’t listen.. Thought they would fall 6 feet to the floor lol..

I found it interesting that Destin asked about the possibility of an appy happening while on a boat ( @11:30). When I was a Corpsman I remember my Senior Chief, who was a Sub IDC, telling me about that exact scenario. I don't know why the story has stuck with me all these years but the Corpsman/Pharmacist's Mate's name was Wheeler B. Lipes who in fact performed that exact surgery in the galley of a boat. While I understand the IDC's apprehension to answering the question, and I don't fault him one bit. I have no doubt that he would step up to the occasion if it were absolutely necessary. I remember another Corpsman and I working 4 days straight without sleep to keep someone alive at sea. I am very proud to say that individual is still with us today. You do what you have to do to get your crew back home alive.

A couple of points.  When I was on subs, before laptops, the yeoman typed all the op reports, so he had one of the highest security clearances on the boat. The reason they put you in the XO’s stateroom is because it’s the only unoccupied rack. Putting you somewhere else would have meant 3 more guys would have had to hotrack in 2 bunks.  I’ve watched the Doc stitch guys, fill teeth, etc.  They are special duty corpsmen with lots of extra training. My first corpsman had a bronze star and Purple Heart from serving with the Marines in Vietnam. Oddly enough, I don’t remember the names of any of the corpsmen on the two boats in 6 1/2 years of sea duty.  They were just “Doc”.

If you hear the term "Water Buffalo" you've been in there too long. If you are in there too long, they shut the hot water valve off on you (which is located outside of the shower stall)....

Also, you think that rack was bad? Wait until you get to sleep next to a torpedo.

The ad for this video had a white woman with a jogger. I'm so sick of that small hat propaganda. I'd not normally see it, but it's time for youtube's annual anti-adblocking blitz.

Also, Destin... If you want the "authentic experience"... You should choose between the two... Enlisted or Officer, and of course... They had you spoiled as an officer and didn't want you to be where and how the enlisted were, why? Because simply... You'd hate it and it'd be a VERY bad image from the Navy. The Navy isn't for everyone (especially the enlisted side)... It's rough and it takes time to deal with it. It's just like everyone would talk about their job publicly... They wouldn't like to portray the worst, only the good. I hope everyone including you understands it and of course I know you know more about things you've seen that wouldn't like to express in public. I'm sure there were some sailors that told you differently or they had "selected" sailors to accompany you. Overall... I'm glad you had a great experience on board that sub, you'd love a experience from the enlisted point of view though you'd see a better picture of what we do. Hooyah!

Yeah, you've literally got a good meal and yes... Submariners get better food; however, even though they're the hardest sailors to be... You should visit a DDG. Morale is a must everywhere you go and everyone does it differently, but sadly... It's NEVER enough. Hooyah Navy!

I spent 8 years attached to 688 & 688i subs as a sonar technician and used this exact same toilet during those years. Pressure.... I have a Druck pressure meter that came from a navy vessel. It was supposedly used to measure the pressure difference between sections of the ship. The idear being to have the highest pressure in the most inner sections of the ship and progressively decrease towards the outside to assure the evacuation of smoke and smells but also to prevent any dangerous gasses, smoke or hazardous gasses entering the ship.. Perhaps the subs move air around on purpose to scrub the air from one area to another by changing the pressures in different sections of the sub... Also to emulate natural air pressure changes   in the atmosphere to not destabilise the bodys natural reactions to changes in air pressure.

I just discovered this tiny French "science" channel where a young guy and his friends take a shot at building the world's largest and highest water rocket (perhaps a record that should be on your name, but hey).
It's very interesting as he shows his entire process, however simple it is, including all his mistakes, and the near disaster at launch. The 40ft (!!) tall rocket flew 335yards high, and topped out at 200mph! His scientific process seems to be alright, but he seems to be bummed over the total loss, and slightly demotivated by this "failure".
He says he will now first try a more proven method for ballistic rockets and at a smaller scale, but I think young scientists should dare to dream, and those dreams should not be held back by every day life constraints like jobs to get food on the table. I believe all good content creators are artists (in addition to some of them being genius scientists or craftsmen) and we should all be patrons of the arts...

Fun Fact: The "World's Worst Bidet" as you were calling it... there is a VERY good reason you don't go when the sewage system is being flushed overboard. If a step is missed, and the pressure shoots back into the water closet by mistake... it can potentially be lethal. As in the back pressure has the very real possibilty of blasting back up INTO the toilet, at hundreds to thousands of PSI, and acting like a very nasty pressure washer with several hundred gallons of waste water erupting into the toilet bowl. That's one of the reasons there is a BALL valve there, instead of just a simple flapper valve. The ball valve can become the last line of defense against such an event, and be the difference between someone pooping at the wrong time and getting scared by the pipes suddenly banging about... and a suddenly dead crew member dying in one of the most horrific ways possible.

That is why the crew who deals with that system is trained RIGOROUSLY on the proper procedures of how to flush the waste systems properly, and why each toilet has it's own set and regimented procedure for flushing it. It is also why the showers and sinks also have their own set of pipes and valves as well, that are NOT common connected like they would be in a house. The systems are separated to a point, and beyond THAT point, downstream if you will, they are common connected, but the pipes leading up to that point are all separate.

When I was in boy scouts, I got to stay the night onboard the USS Pampanito, which is a WWII era Balao-class diesel-electric submarine with a pretty interesting story behind her. You may have seen the movie "The Bridge on the River Kwai." Well, the Pampanito was involved in the real-life incident that movie is based on, in which she transported 73 liberated British and Australian POWs back to safety. Not only that, but she was also used for the exterior shots in the movie "Down Periscope" (which is a hilarious movie, by the way, military comedy at its finest). She's now permanently docked in San Francisco not too far from Fisherman's Wharf, where she now serves as a naval museum.

The reason the pressure in the ship was at 794 Torr was because the ship had taken a pressure so that they could do air charges to recharge the air banks.  Give it a few days as they do air charges and from breathing the pressure will actually drop. It drops from just the act of breathing because as you breath you expel CO2, which in turn is scrubbed by the CO2 scrubbers, which absorbs the CO2 using Amine, and then is pumped overboard.  Hope this helps.  -Retired ET/SS

Hey Destin!, retired Sub Sailor here. Enjoying the series! The air pressure segment in this video was great. Lots of things on the boat use high pressure air to operate, and the air venting into the boat is one of the causes for pressure to increase. running the HPAC (High Pressure Air Compressor) to charge the ship's high pressure air banks draws air from inside the ship, and can cause the pressure to decrease.

I spent 14 of 20 years as a cook on submarines. Since there is only one Corpsman onboard, the cooks are trained as EMT's to help him out. During a casualty we were the ones to go to and stabilize the patient and carry them back to the wardroom for medical care. We were trained in BLS (basic life support), how to do stitches, do EKG's and insert IV's. If we had someone who needed 24 hour care, we helped care for them while Doc got some rest. We once had a crewmember cut off a finger while at sea and I spent all night helping Doc sew it back on until we could get him off the boat to a medical facility.

Sometime during the night the Auxiliaryman on watch will pressurized the black/sanitary tank to a few psi above sea pressure, open a hull valve and push the contents out to sea.  Generally its done at a shallower depth because it requires less pressure.  After the tank is empty the hull valve is shut and the residual pressure is vented onboard, yep, A bit smelly.  So the internal pressure in the boat may go up a little depending on how deep the boat is when this takes place.  When I was in it was acceptable to pea in the toilet but not flush until the pressure was normalized.  You know how you do a lot of things automatically, well open that flush valve with out thinking and you'll have a mess to clean up.

In honour of Ensign Rex Murphy, US Navy, WW2, salute!
What happened to him was, all flushes on the submarine he was in went into a holding tank, for later flushing into the sea.
During one depth-charge attack, the valve controlling that broke.
So for hours Ensign Rex Murphy stayed at his post, holding that valve shut, preventing the contents from blasting into the submarine.
For hours, sometimes losing his grip because of depth-charging, he stayed at his post!

As a former Damage Control Assistant (DCA) onboard a US Coast Guard 210' cutter, the "deck plates" (blurred images at 19:50) are used with grease pens to make notations on during engineering casualties. The symbols are constant among the fleet. So if you looked at one on a NAVY vessel and saw the symbol for a "Bravo" class fire it is the same symbol that is used on a Coast Guard cutter. I was on a submarine back in the late 80s and early 90s. Speaking about atmospheric pressure, the pressure in the living spaces fluctuates slightly because of the use of pneumatics and air compressors. Once when we surfaced the pressure was a little lower inside the sub than the pressure on the surface. When they equalized the pressure with the outside, I had a full squirt bottle of shampoo that shot all over the inside of my locker.

Ice cream on waffles is a travesty. It's a waste of both.

1. It's difficult to eat. Neither a fork nor a spoon work well. Once you manage to cut off a piece of waffle and get a bit of ice cream on it, good luck getting that into your mouth without the ice cream slipping off. Forks are for waffles, spoons are for ice cream, and putting them together is every kind of wrong.

2. Both taste better separately. Waffles need to be served piping hot. Cold waffles are yucky. Ice cream on a hot waffle becomes soup in nothing flat, and runs everywhere but on the waffle. Cold waffles taste like cardboard, are merely a (very inefficient) vehicle to get the ice cream into your mouth, and just make it harder to eat.

Waffles are hot breakfast, not cold dessert, just like pancakes. And no, crepes are NOT pancakes.

If you want strawberry favored waffles, use fresh chopped strawberries or strawberry syrup, and you can always add fresh cream. The result tastes far better than with ice cream and doesn't have the melting and balancing issues.

Thank you for this entire wonderful series!! As a former submariner I have found it all fascinating. I was hoping after the Torpedo Tube Crawl video which included HOW the weapons get in and out of the sub and down to the torpedo room, there might be more about how these large heavy weapons are moved around in the torpedo room. Its probably WAAAAY too late because months have passed since you left the Toledo, but I am forever trying to figure out the details of:
1.) How are weapons "rammed" in and out of the tubes, and what are the details of this ram system? Hydraulic drive chain drive???
2.) How are the four weapon loading trays (one per tube) pivoted from strict fore-aft alignment to the approx 11 degree angle of the tubes?
3.) How are weapons transferred from the upper (tubes #1 & 2) "stow" level to the lower (tubes #3 & 4) "stow" level and visa versa? It almost has to be by hydraulic hoists of some type stowed below each of the port & starboard walking decks.
4.) How are weapons moved from port to starboard within each "stow" area? There are outboard stow areas on both stow levels and the one large center stow area per level between the two aisles. Every weapon enters the room initially from above onto the center of the upper stow area and must be moved anywhere from there, including crossing the two aisles.

I served on the Dace SSN 607 in the early 80s. I remember distinctly 2 things things about the toilet system. after pressurizing the holding tanks to discharge overboard, that air had to be released to be able to use them again. Inboard. and if you were unlucky enough to have a bunk near the air vent - oh boy! the charcoal filters were of little help! and second a prank sometimes played on the new junior officer. All the toilets/bathrooms had to be marked Do Not Use prior to pressurizing the tanks, so someone would watch for the junior officer go into the head and quickly then start pressurizing the tank. When said officer turned around and bent down face first to open the 'flush valve" he got a facefull! lol Good times

Related trivia: In the days prior to nuclear submarines, there were no complex pressurized seawater systems, and most submarines used onboard septic tanks to hold their waste. These tanks could only be emptied when surfaced, which was usually not a problem, as subs in those days rarely stayed submerged for more than a day or so. A few German U-boats had a more advanced toilet system installed that was basically a miniature airlock; this allowed waste to be flushed out at any depth, and eliminated the need for an onboard septic tank, but it was very complicated to use and required a dedicated toilet technician to operate and maintain. One boat, U-1206, was actually lost when the toilet malfunctioned and flooded the boat's batteries with seawater, forcing it to surface where it was then sunk by Allied bombers.

Some questions about (american) toilets: what is the purpose of that gap at the front of the toilet seat? I have seen this exclusively in America, but nowhere else in the world. It has always puzzled me that the toilet seat isn't one continuous loop.
Also: do most toilets in the USA really not have a half-flush button (for saving water)? And why on earth is it that it is apparently normal to have half an inch of a gap between the wall and the toilet door?? When walking past the gap and looking through it into the stall, one generally can get a good gander of the person inside it. I don't know about you, but I value my privacy in the restroom. I've even seen doors so low that a standing man could easily have poked his chin above it. Again, I have encountered these issues soleley in America. Haven't seen any of that in Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Britain or Southeast Asia.

Former SSBN yeoman here. It’s funny how so many people (both on and off the boat) always thought that we had nothing to do while we were on patrol when in fact we were still carrying on as if we were in off-crew. Even though we couldn’t mail it, there was seemingly never-ending correspondence we’d be preparing for when we returned. And with one inspection or another basically every patrol (TRE, ORSE, etc.) we were super busy with doing the CO’s report on the inspection. And then there were the enlisted evals and officer FITREPS, upcoming reenlistments and separations, transfers… all sorts of stuff. And of course let’s not forget the CO’s patrol debrief, which was a huge deal, that was completed for each and every patrol.



Sleep. I never slept as well as I did while on patrol. On the former 41 for Freedom boats, crew berthing was in Operations Lower Level. It was always nice and cool and dark and quiet. And if you were fortunate enough to be in the outboard areas of the berthing space, it was almost like being isolated off into a cocoon. It was great!



Showers. LOL After I left the navy and moved back home, for quite a while, I was still subconsciously hyperaware of my water usage. Not to the point of still taking submarine showers but was just aware. Electricity though, couldn’t care less since on the boat you more or less had the ability to generate plenty of electricity. So I was leaving lights on all around the house while being careful with the water. Finally one day my dad said, “Hey… I would rather you leave the water running and turn off all the lights since the water is much cheaper than the electricity.”



Heads. THANK GOD I never joined the 700 Pound Club, also called the Golden Flapper Club! That’s what you join when you blow sh!tters on yourself. But in my five patrols, there were several that did. Let me tell ya; when it happens, everybody knows and they know instantly. The overpressure of that 700 PSI air venting inboard you immediately feel in your ears, and then there’s the tremendous sound that it makes… a roar like a freight train. Urinals… didn’t have them on the 41 for Freedom boats. But you know when you’re qualified toilets when you can flush the toilet without even having to bend over, manipulating the ball valve at the bottom of the bowl with your foot while simultaneously manipulating the gate gave valve your hand to flow some water. hahaha

GREAT series Destin! after almost 49 years OFF the subs, I still take a "submarine shower" My wife on the otherhand........ well...let's just say Happy Wife, Happy Life! During my 6 years on Submarines, I was fortunate enough to never have a malfunction with the sanitary system. The "world's worse bidet" as you called it has other names on the boat...generally the socially accepted term is "venting inboard"...the ball valve is usually referred to as the "flapper" due to the long lever that cycles the valve...so when someone vents inboard on themselves (and it is NOT pleasant!!) they are generally awarded the "golden Flapper award" a dubious honor at best and one that lives on for years in the retelling of the incident. Submarine crews are amazing...and that brotherhood is strong. I am still in contact with many of my shipmates and they are my brothers still. In September my boat (which no longer exists except in the hearts and memories of her crew) will have a reunion in San Antonio...and so far there are more than 50 crewmembers planning on going, and hopefully more will join in. The reunion is for the entire crew for the entire life of the boat from the early 60's to the late 80's so it goes from Plank Owners ( commissioning crew) to Decomm.
Respect

Cribbage is one of the most boring card games ever invented.  More time spent shuffling, staring at the cards in your hand determining which are the best 4 to keep. Then a very short period of actual play (interacting with cards other than yours) where you just add and count out loud and pegging for different points made a grand total of 16 cards played in 4 player or 8 cards in two player.  Then back to staring at your cards and other cards trying to find and count the points that are there, and then moving your peg the correct number of places... then looking at the crib and doing the same thing...  LAME GAME!  Slow and boring.  Very little strategy.  A limited number of hands that can be made, and a great amount of luck based on what the flipped card is.

Destin, my man, another great episode! You make me proud to be from Alabama, and that bit on Code Switching hit really close to home. My Southern accent only ever comes out when I'm fired up about something, or meet another Southerner. Anyways, you have a great knack for making seeming uninteresting things fascinating. Who would have thought using the bathroom or medical stuff would be so difficult on a sub? Who even thinks about doing that kind of stuff? I'm an Army vet, and even I, for some reason only think of subs as a scout/combat thing, for some reason my mind glosses over the fact that they're on those ships for months on end. Being on a ship that long must make every single normal aspect of life different. When you were in the bathroom and mentioned wanting to read the stuff above the toilet, it made me think how much I take having a smart phone for granted, I can't remember the last time I read a physical book on the loo, haha. Keep doing what you do, keep making Alabama proud, keep making us all smarter, and Roll Tide.

Re: NAVY SHOWER

This is a real term, and involves using a rapid shutoff valve (aka a "water saver") so that you only use just enough water to get wet, and to rinse off, instead of simply letting the water run for the whole duration, which saves a LOT of water. They're usually paired with low flow shower heads that generate a wide fine spray that covers better while also using less water courtesy of a lower total flow rate.

Even if you dont serve in the navy, learning how to take a navy style shower is good for the environment, and it will extend the life of your home's cesspool if you have one.

My wife is an incurable water baby, but water efficiency was drummed into me at a young age by Depression Era parents and grandparents, 4 of 6 of whom were veterans of WWII & WWI respectively.

We were warned about that.  :)
